column1: #Text=Surely the golden hours are turning gray And dance no more , and vainly strive to run :
#Text=I see their white locks streaming in the wind --
#Text=Each face is haggard as it looks at me , Slow turning in the constant clasping round Storm-driven .

#Text=Dorothea 's distress when she was leaving the church came chiefly from the perception that Mr. Casaubon was determined not to speak to his cousin , and that Will 's presence at church had served to mark more strongly the alienation between them .
#Text=Will 's coming seemed to her quite excusable , nay , she thought it an amiable movement in him towards a reconciliation which she herself had been constantly wishing for .
#Text=He had probably imagined , as she had , that if Mr. Casaubon and he could meet easily , they would shake hands and friendly intercourse might return .
#Text=But now Dorothea felt quite robbed of that hope .
#Text=Will was banished further than ever , for Mr. Casaubon must have been newly embittered by this thrusting upon him of a presence which he refused to recognize .

#Text=He had not been very well that morning , suffering from some difficulty in breathing , and had not preached in consequence ; she was not surprised , therefore , that he was nearly silent at luncheon , still less that he made no allusion to Will Ladislaw .
#Text=For her own part she felt that she could never again introduce that subject .

#Text=They usually spent apart the hours between luncheon and dinner on a Sunday ; Mr. Casaubon in the library dozing chiefly , and Dorothea in her boudoir , where she was wont to occupy herself with some of her favorite books .

#Text=There was a little heap of them on the table in the bow-window -- of various sorts , from Herodotus , which she was learning to read with Mr. Casaubon , to her old companion Pascal , and Keble 's " Christian Year .

#Text= But to-day she opened one after another , and could read none of them .

_	_	_	_

#Text=This proposal was only one more sign added to many since his memorable interview with Lydgate , that Mr. Casaubon 's original reluctance to let Dorothea work with him had given place to the contrary disposition , namely , to demand much interest and labor from her .
